metadata.case_name: Lalji Haridas v. Income-tax Officer, Ward D, Jamnagar & Anr.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in High Court of Gujarat under Article 226 praying for writ of certiorari quashing two notices issued by respondent No. 1 (Income-tax Officer) on 14th April 1960 and 7th July 1960, and assessment order passed on 17th December 1958.
High Court dismissed the writ petition in limine without issuing notice to respondents.
Appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court against dismissal of writ petition.
Assessment order passed against appellant on 17th December 1958 assessing him to pay income-tax on Rs. 4,74,046 for assessment year 1949-50.

Notice issued to appellant on 20th December 1957 under section 46(1)(a) of Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance, 1949 (corresponding to section 34(1)(a) of Indian Income-tax Act) as income had escaped assessment.
Appellant made return showing income of Rs. 46 for the year.

Several amounts credited in appellant's account books: on 24th October 1948, Rs. 1 lakh to M/s. Bhagirath Madangopal Co., Bombay, and Rs. 1 lakh to Mulji Manilal Kamdar (later transferred to M/s. Bhagirath Kasat Co.); on 7th March 1949, Rs. 1,80,000 transferred to M/s. Bhagirath Kasat Co.; further credits of Rs. 74,000 and Rs. 20,000.
Appellant claimed credits represented benami transactions on behalf of others, not his income.
Income-tax Officer not satisfied with explanation and passed assessment order.
Appellant appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, Rajkot, contending witnesses not examined and evidence not recorded properly.

Appellate Assistant Commissioner partly accepted contention, remanded proceedings to Income-tax Officer on 3rd September 1959 to examine witnesses and submit report; commented on appellant's dilatory tactics.
After remand, Income-tax Officer issued letters dated 13th April 1960 and 7th July 1960 requiring appellant to appear and give evidence.
Appellant filed writ petition in Gujarat High Court on 9th July 1960 instead of complying.
Appellant also preferred appeal from remand order to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.
Proceedings before Income-tax Officer stayed after writ filing.

legal_issues.text: Whether writ petition under Article 226 maintainable to challenge notices as barred by time, assessment as protective levy, or remand order as illegal to save limitation.
Validity of Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance under which proceedings commenced.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notice issued under section 46(1)(a) barred by time.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner illegally remanded case instead of treating assessment as nullity to save limitation.
Assessment order of 17th December 1958 is protective assessment as other persons taxed on same transactions.
Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance invalid (later conceded not pressed).

court_reasoning.text: No substance in appeal; illustrates assessee prolonging proceedings via judicial remedies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appeal must be dismissed with costs.

court_reasoning.text: Plea of notice barred by time must be raised before Income-tax Officer, not High Court under Article 226; jurisdiction under Article 226 not to supersede tax authorities' merits jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plea not specifically raised in writ petition.

court_reasoning.text: Ground in writ re remand saving limitation irrelevant to initial notice being time-barred.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Such pleas inappropriate in writ proceedings.

court_reasoning.text: Protective assessment plea vague, not on oath that others paid tax; must be raised before Income-tax Officer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot be urged in writ under Article 226.

holdings.text: Writ jurisdiction under Article 226 not for raising pleas like limitation or protective assessment which tax authorities must consider on merits.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction for writ petition not to supersede tax authorities' merits consideration

statutes_cited.name: Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice issued for escaped assessment; corresponds to section 34(1)(a) of Indian Income-tax Act

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Corresponds to section 46(1)(a) of Saurashtra Ordinance

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed with costs; writ petition against notices and assessment order properly dismissed by High Court in limine.

key_quotes.text: this appeal illustrates how an assessee can prolong the assessment proceedings by adopting judicial proceedings available to him under the law and thereby postpone indefinitely the final disposal
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights court's view on dilatory tactics by assessee

key_quotes.text: The jurisdiction conferred on the High Court under article 226 is not intended to supersede the jurisdiction and authority of the Income-tax Officers to deal with the merits of all the contentions that the assessees may raise before them
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines limits of writ jurisdiction in tax matters
